On Wed, 24 Sep 2003, Ray Tayek wrote:

> At 09:35 AM 9/24/03 -0400, you wrote:
> >On Wednesday, September 24, 2003, at 3:11:08 AM, Chris Dollin wrote:
> >It's time for a test.
>
> a simple test seems to indicate no difference using 1.4.1_01-b-1, mixed
> mode. the times seem the same on a 1 ghz windows box, while the long names
> seem to be a little *faster* on a 350 mhz slak box. maybe i have a bug in
> my test :(

In this form the test doesn't measure what we are talking about: the
long names are local variables that become integer stack offsets in
the bytecode.  These names do not go in the constant pool.

That is, since the test doesn't measure I/O, there should be no effect
at all.  But there is.  The long names ran consistently faster in the
Java tests. Since the test runs in a continuous loop, this can't be the
result of any startup effect.

FWIW I translated the Java into C++ and ran the same benchmark.  Oddly
enough, the variable name length definitely has a pronounced effect
in C++.  On a slow PC used as a test box, results looked like this:

           Java    C++ -O1    C++ -O2
short      13.4s     3.2s       4.1s
long       12.0s     8.4s       7.2s

memory use 12.4 MB   0.8 MB     0.8 MB

Turning up the optimization on the C++ code had the disturbing effect
of slowing down the short-name tests while improving the long-name
results.  Further optimization produced no clear benefit.

The machine was running RedHat 8.0 Linux, gcc 3.x, Sun Java 1.4.1_02,
and X.  It was otherwise idle.  It has a CPU clocked at 533 MHz.

If you include startup times, C++'s performance advantage over Java
improves.  However, it comes as a pleasant surprise that Java comes
this close to C++.
